facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 546 of 1962 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 546 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 17, 1958 of the Allahabad High Court in Misc. Case No. 152 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 17, 1958 of the Allahabad High Court in Misc. Case No. 152 of 1952.

facts.text: Bijli Cotton Mills is the respondent in this appeal and is a manufacturer of cotton yarn.

anchor.surface_text: Bijli Cotton Mills-respondent in this appeal-is a manufacturer of companyton yarn

facts.text: Bijli Cotton Mills is registered as a dealer under the U.P. Sales Tax Act 15 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and is registered as a dealer under the U.P. Sales Tax Act  15 of 1948 .

facts.text: U.P. Sales Tax Act 15 of 1948 came into force on April 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Under the U.P. Sales Tax Act  15 of 1948  which came into force on April 1, 1948,

facts.text: Sales-tax became payable on sales of cotton yarn at a uniform rate of three pies in a rupee.

anchor.surface_text: sales-tax became payable on sales of diverse companymodi- ties including companyton yarn at a uniform rate of three pies in a rupee.

facts.text: By Act 25 of 1948, section 3-A was incorporated in Act 15 of 1948 conferring power on Provincial Government to declare single point taxation.

anchor.surface_text: By Act 25 of 1948, s. 3-A was incorporated in Act 15 of 1948 companyferring upon the Provincial Government power to declare by numberification

facts.text: Under section 7 as amended by Act 25 of 1948, a dealer had option to submit return on turnover of previous year or current year.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 7 as amended by Act 25 of 1948, a dealer had the option to submit his return on the basis of the turnover of the sales in the previous year

facts.text: The respondent company opted to be assessed on the basis of the turnover of the previous year ending March 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companypany opted to be assessed on the basis of the turnover of the previous year ending March 31, 1948.

facts.text: Government of U.P. issued notification under s. 3-A declaring that from June 9, 1948, proceeds of cotton yarn shall be included in turnover at single point.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the power under s. 3-A of the Act the Government of U.P. issued a numberification declaring that with effect from June 9, 1948,

facts.text: From June 9, 1949, rate of tax for cotton yarn was six pies per rupee at single point.

facts.text: Sales-tax Officer, Hathras assessed respondent for 1948-49 at three pies for first 69 days and six pies for remaining part.

holdings.text: Section 31 makes sales-tax exigible from an assessee who has opted to pay tax on the turnover of the previous year, as if the altered rates were in force during the previous year. The turnover of the previous year must therefore be broken up, the new rate of tax being applicable proportionately for the same number of days in the previous year as were in force in the assessment year.

anchor.surface_text: Section 31 makes sales-tax exigible from an assessee who has, opted to pay tax on the turnover of the previous year, as if the altered rates were in force during the previous year. The turnover of the previous year must therefore be broken up, the new rate of tax being applicable proportionately for the same number of days as they are in force during the assessment year. The amendment is retroactive, and applies to assessments pending or closed, as if the validating Act had been in force at the material date. This Court had in the Modi Sugar Mills Ltd.s case 1 held -that where the assessee had elected to submit his return on the turnover of the previous year under s. 7 of Act 15 of 1948 as amended by Act 25 of 1948 he was liable to be assessed to -sales-tax at the rate in force on the first day of the year of assessment, because the liability arises on that date, and any subsequent enhancement of the rate by virtue of a notification under s. 3-A does not alter that liability.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of s.31(1) which deems assessment year rates applicable proportionately to previous year turnover for opted dealers.

holdings.text: The amendment is retroactive, and applies to assessments pending or closed, as if the validating Act had been in force at the material date.

anchor.surface_text: The amendment is retroactive, and applies to assessments pending or closed, as if the validating Act had been in force at the material date. This Court had in the Modi Sugar Mills Ltd.s case 1 held -that where the assessee had elected to submit his return on the turnover of the previous year under s. 7 of Act 15 of 1948 as amended by Act 25 of 1948 he was liable to be assessed to -sales-tax at the rate in force on the first day of the year of assessment, because the liability arises on that date, and any subsequent enhancement of the rate by virtue of a notification under s. 3-A does not alter that liability. The view expressed by the Court has been modified by express legislation operative retrospectively.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.31 expressly retrospective from April 1, 1948, with validating clause deeming prior actions valid.

holdings.text: The view expressed by the Court has been modified by express legislation operative retrospectively. The liability to tax of the turnover of the previous year which is regarded as the fictional turnover of the year of assessment has to be determined on the basis that the rates applicable in the year of assessment were fictionally projected on the taxable turnover.

anchor.surface_text: This Court had in the Modi Sugar Mills Ltd.s case 1 held -that where the assessee had elected to submit his return on the turnover of the previous year under s. 7 of Act 15 of 1948 as amended by Act 25 of 1948 he was liable to be assessed to -sales-tax at the rate in force on the first day of the year of assessment, because the liability arises on that date, and any subsequent enhancement of the rate by virtue of a notification under s. 3-A does not alter that liability. The view expressed by the Court has been modified by express legislation operative retrospectively. The liability to tax of the turnover of the previous year which is regarded as the fictional turnover of the year of assessment has to be determined on the basis that the rates applicable in the year of assessment were fictionally projected on the taxable turnover.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Retrospective legislation overrides and modifies prior Supreme Court interpretation in Modi Sugar Mills.

holdings.text: In our view there is no substance in this contention. [...] In answering the question which was submitted by the Judge Revisions Sales Tax, therefore, the law enacted by the Legislature is the law found incorporated in s. 31 by Amending Act III of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: In our view there is no substance in this contention. The question referred to the High Court posed a problem as to the liability of the respondent company to be assessed for the assessment year 1948-49. Two rival views were propounded before the Judge Revisions Sales Tax. One was that the rates applicable to the fictional turnover for the year of assessment were those prevalent in the year 1948-49 and for the purpose of assessment they had to be applied to the turnover in the same proportion in which they would have applied if the option had not been exercised. That was the contention of the Sales Tax Department. The contention of the assessee was that having opted for the turnover of the previous year, the rates applicable to the turnover would be crystallised on the first day of the year of assessment and any modification since the commencement of the year in the rates would be inapplicable. This Court in the Modi Sugar Mills Ltd.s case 1 accepted the contention raised by the assessee. But for the amendment, the question which was posed by the Judge Revisions Sales Tax would have to be answered as it was answered by the High Court. The Legislature has, however, amended the Act and has declared that notwithstanding the option exercised by the assessee the tax would have to be computed in the light of the rates prevailing in 1948-49 as if they were projected upon the turnover of the previous year. The Legislature has expressly stated that this rule will prevail as if it was in force during the assessment year and all assessments will be made in the light of this amended rule. In answering the question which was submitted by the Judge Revisions Sales Tax, therefore, the law enacted by the Legislature is the law found incorporated in s. 31 by Amending Act III of 1963.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax reference jurisdiction requires applying retrospectively operative law deemed in force at material time, giving effect to legislative intent without altering referred question.

holdings.text: The doubt expressed was therefore in respect of the power of the Court to decide a question other than the question which was actually referred and not in respect of the power and indeed the duty of the High Court to apply to the question referred the law enacted with retroactive operation.

anchor.surface_text: The doubt expressed was therefore in respect of the power of the Court to decide a question other than the question which was actually referred and not in respect of the power and indeed the duty of the High Court to apply to the question referred the law enacted with retroactive operation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Chatturam Horilram: applies to changing the question vs. applying retroactive law to referred question.

holdings.text: But in that case, in the view of the High Court the amendment made by the amending statute of 1962 which came into force after the reference was made by the Income-tax Tribunal had no retrospective operation [...]. The observation therefore does not assist the contention that even in cases where the relevant statute has been amended with retroactive operation [...].

anchor.surface_text: But in that case, in the view of the High Court the amendment made by the amending statute of 1962 which came into force after the reference was made by the Income-tax Tribunal had no retrospective operation, and the question referred by the Tribunal had to be answered by the High Court in the light of the relevant law applicable at the date of the transaction. The observation relied upon has to be read in the context of the finding of the High Court as to the character of the amending legislation. The observation therefore does not assist the contention that even in cases where the relevant statute has been amended with retroactive operation, so as to apply to the transaction which forms the subject-matter of the reference, and the High Court or this Court is bound in recording its opinion on the question referred to ignore the amended law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Rampur Distillery: amendment there lacked retrospective effect, unlike here.

holdings.text: On the view taken by us this appeal must be allowed and the question raised by the Judge Revisions Sales Tax must be answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: On the view taken by us this appeal must be allowed and the question raised by the Judge Revisions Sales Tax must be answered in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of s.31 retrospective provisions to referred question on tax rates for opted assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Section 31 makes sales-tax exigible from an assessee who has, opted to pay tax on the turnover of the previous year, as if the altered rates were in force during the previous year. The turnover of the previous year must therefore be broken up, the new rate of tax being applicable proportionately for the same number of days as they are in force during the assessment year. The amendment is retroactive, and applies to assessments pending or closed, as if the validating Act had been in force at the material date. This Court had in the Modi Sugar Mills Ltd.s case 1 held -that where the assessee had elected to submit his return on the turnover of the previous year under s. 7 of Act 15 of 1948 as amended by Act 25 of 1948 he was liable to be assessed to -sales-tax at the rate in force on the first day of the year of assessment, because the liability arises on that date, and any subsequent enhancement of the rate by virtue of a notification under s. 3-A does not alter that liability.
On the view taken by us this appeal must be allowed and the question raised by the Judge  Revisions  Sales Tax must be answered in the affirmative.

The view expressed by the Court has been modified by express legislation operative retrospectively.

edges.explanation: h4 directly addresses i2 by rejecting the contention that the court must answer the referred question solely based on law at the time of the transaction, using 'no substance' language tied to pith and substance analysis, and requiring consideration of subsequent legislation

anchor.surface_text: In our view there is no substance in this contention. The question referred to the High Court posed a problem as to the liability of the respondent company to be assessed for the assessment year 1948-49. Two rival views were propounded before the Judge Revisions Sales Tax. One was that the rates applicable to the fictional turnover for the year of assessment were those prevalent in the year 1948-49 and for the purpose of assessment they had to be applied to the turnover in the same proportion in which they would have applied if the option had not been exercised. That was the contention of the Sales Tax Department. The contention of the assessee was that having opted for the turnover of the previous year, the rates applicable to the turnover would be crystallised on the first day of the year of assessment and any modification since the commencement of the year in the rates would be inapplicable. This Court in the Modi Sugar Mills Ltd.s case 1 accepted the contention raised by the assessee. But for the amendment, the question which was posed by the Judge Revisions Sales Tax would have to be answered as it was answered by the High Court. The Legislature has, however, amended the Act and has declared that notwithstanding the option exercised by the assessee the tax would have to be computed in the light of the rates prevailing in 1948-49 as if they were projected upon the turnover of the previous year. The Legislature has expressly stated that this rule will prevail as if it was in force during the assessment year and all assessments will be made in the light of this amended rule. In answering the question which was submitted by the Judge Revisions Sales Tax, therefore, the law enacted by the Legislature is the law found incorporated in s. 31 by Amending Act III of 1963.
On the view taken by us this appeal must be allowed and the question raised by the Judge  Revisions  Sales Tax must be answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The doubt expressed was therefore in respect of the power of the Court to decide a question other than the question which was actually referred and not in respect of the power and indeed the duty of the High Court to apply to the question referred the law enacted with retroactive operation.
On the view taken by us this appeal must be allowed and the question raised by the Judge  Revisions  Sales Tax must be answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: But in that case, in the view of the High Court the amendment made by the amending statute of 1962 which came into force after the reference was made by the Income-tax Tribunal had no retrospective operation, and the question referred by the Tribunal had to be answered by the High Court in the light of the relevant law applicable at the date of the transaction. The observation relied upon has to be read in the context of the finding of the High Court as to the character of the amending legislation. The observation therefore does not assist the contention that even in cases where the relevant statute has been amended with retroactive operation, so as to apply to the transaction which forms the subject-matter of the reference, and the High Court or this Court is bound in recording its opinion on the question referred to ignore the amended law.
On the view taken by us this appeal must be allowed and the question raised by the Judge  Revisions  Sales Tax must be answered in the affirmative.
